DOCNAME: DES FOURS WALDERODE v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON Fours Walderode , was a NORP and NORP national . He was born in DATE and died on DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s widow , PERSON , informed the ORG that she wished to pursue the application originally lodged by her husband , who had designated her as his universal heir . She is an NORP national , born in DATE , and lives in GPE , GPE . Having regard to its practice in similar cases , the ORG accepted PERSON as the person entitled to pursue the application ( see GPE v. GPE DATE . ) , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-XII , with further references ) .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .

PERSON , the applicant ’s stepmother , PERSON and PERSON , his stepbrothers , all NORP nationals , owned real estate in former GPE . In DATE the property owned by the applicant ’s stepbrothers and part of the property owned by the applicant ’s stepmother was confiscated pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on LAW , NORP , NORP and Enemies of the NORP and NORP nations ( dekret presidenta republiky ze dne DATE . června DATE konfiskaci a urychleném rozdělení zemědělského majetku Němců , ORG , jakož i zrádců a nepřátel českého a slovenského národa ) , which entered into force on DATE . The remainder of the property of the applicant ’s stepmother was confiscated pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on ORG and National Restoration Funds ( dekret presidenta republiky ze dne DATE . října CARDINAL o konfiskaci nepřátelského majetku a GPE národní obnovy ) , on DATE , on the ground that she had been a NORP and that her sons , PERSON and GPE , had served in PERSON ’s ORG troops .
PERSON , the applicant ’s father , had sold his real estate to third persons on an unknown date before the Second World War .

PERSON died on DATE . PERSON served in ORG during the Second World War and was declared to be presumed dead as from DATE by ORG ( Amtgericht ) on DATE . The applicant ’s stepmother died on CARDINAL DATE . She left her real estate to the applicant , conferring the succession rights of her deceased sons , PERSON and GPE , on the applicant . She had never acquired NORP citizenship .
The applicant left GPE in DATE , thereby forfeiting his NORP citizenship , and returned in DATE . NORP citizenship was granted him on DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s legal representative lodged a claim for the restitution of the property confiscated from his stepmother and stepbrothers under Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and which had been sold by his father before the Second World War . He referred to LAW of DATE ( see the “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” below ) , alleging that he had inherited the property .

On DATE the GPE nad ORG ( pozemkový úřad ) dismissed the applicant ’s claim in proceedings to which CARDINAL municipalities and CARDINAL other legal persons - the owners of the property at the material time - were parties . ORG held that the applicant ’s stepmother and stepbrothers had not been loyal to the NORP State during the NORP occupation ( DATE ) and had not acquired NORP citizenship after the Second World War . It referred to the documentary evidence , including the decision of ORG národní výbor ) of CARDINAL DATE confiscating the remainder of the stepmother ’s property under Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the ground that she had been a NORP and that her sons , PERSON and GPE , had served in PERSON ’s ORG troops .

ORG found that the property at issue had been put under national administration in DATE , that it had subsequently been confiscated pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , and that the real estate of the applicant ’s father had been transferred to third persons before the Second World War . It concluded , with reference to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE , that the applicant was not the owner of the property as his stepmother and stepbrothers ( the original owners of the property ) had not satisfied the requirements for restitution set out in this LAW , and that the applicant ’s claim in respect of his father ’s former property fell outside the scope of the restitution legislation .

The applicant appealed to ORG ( městský soud ) , through his counsel , against the administrative decision , alleging , inter alia , that ORG had not sufficiently established the facts of the case . He also argued that his stepmother had waived her deceased PERSON succession rights in his favour , and that neither she nor his stepbrothers had been NORP . He maintained that Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL should not have been applied to his stepbrothers because at the time of its entry into force ( DATE ) his stepbrothers were dead . The applicant further claimed that , during the NORP occupation , the NORP legal system had been in force in the territory of former GPE . He claimed that under LAW of DATE , an estate passed to the heirs upon the death of a testator and that therefore CARDINAL of GPE ’s property had passed to his stepmother , DATE to PERSON and DATE to himself . In these circumstances , he had inherited CARDINAL of GPE ’s property on DATE and part of PERSON ’s property on DATE in the form of hereditas iacens ( ležící pozůstalost ; “ dormant ” inheritance ; ruhender ORG ) ( see page CARDINAL below , LAW ) . He further claimed that , as his stepmother had conferred her deceased PERSON succession rights on him , he had acquired the whole estate .

On DATE ORG , after having assessed a substantial amount of documentary evidence and having heard the parties to the dispute , upheld ORG decision . The court , refusing to grant the applicant leave to appeal , said in particular :

“ The court does not share the applicant ’s opinion that he was the owner of the property as at the time when the confiscation under Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL took place , PERSON and PERSON were registered in ORG as the owners of the property .

In its legal analysis , the court considered Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on ORG , which expresses the principle of the legal continuity of the NORP legal order . The Decree provides that legal provisions enacted up to CARDINAL DATE ... constituted part of the NORP legal order ; those adopted during the NORP occupation ( DATE and DATE ) did not form part of the NORP legal order ... However , the Decree defined certain legal provisions enacted on NORP territory under the NORP occupation which could be applied during a transitional period , provided that they were not contrary to LAW ...
Act no . CARDINAL on the Applicability of Legal Regulations from DATE annulled the applicability of all legal provisions enacted during the NORP occupation ...

By LAW by NORP Citizens of NORP Nationality of DATE , NORP citizens of NORP nationality living on the territory of former GPE on DATE acquired NORP citizenship with effect from DATE ... at the latest .

In order to determine the citizenship of GPE and PERSON , regard has to be had to the President PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the NORP citizenship of NORP and NORP nationals , under which NORP or NORP nationals lost their NORP citizenship by acquiring NORP or NORP citizenship . NORP citizens lost their citizenship on the date when they acquired the citizenship of the foreign occupying power : NORP nationals from the frontier territories of the NORP lands and ORG ( ORG ; GPE ) on DATE , and NORP nationals from other parts of the NORP lands and ORG on DATE .
In these circumstances , it is clear that the applicant ’s stepbrothers acquired NORP citizenship on DATE at the latest ....

In DATE PERSON Fours Walderode was declared to be presumed dead as from DATE , .... His estate , which has not yet been administered , could not have been administered by the national authorities before he was declared to be presumed dead .... Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL recognised exclusively the foreign occupying power ’s measures on the acquisition of NORP citizenship by NORP citizens of NORP nationality . PERSON therefore died on DATE as a NORP citizen . ...

PERSON died in GPE ( former GPE ) on DATE . Having regard to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , he died as a NORP citizen . His estate has not yet been administered by the national authorities . ...

The applicant ’s objection that civil cases brought by NORP citizens residing in the PERSON had to be dealt with under the NORP legal order , until Act no . CARDINAL came into force , is not correct . Actually , Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL annulled only the applicability of those legal acts adopted during the NORP occupation which had been applicable , on a transitional basis , under Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL to the extent that they had not contravened LAW ...
As PERSON lived in GPE and PERSON lived in GPE , they were , at the time of their respective deaths , subject to ORG , which was in force in the NORP lands until DATE ...

Under LAW Civil Code CARDINAL , an heir acquired an estate upon its distribution . The time of acquisition of the estate and death of a testator did not therefore fall within the same period . From the death of a testator until the time of distribution of the estate , the property was subject to hereditas iacens . Before its acquisition by an heir , property subject to hereditas iacens was considered to have been owned by the testator .... In order to assess whether the property subject to hereditas iacens was confiscated from the testator or his heirs , the stage of the inheritance proceedings concerning the property subject to hereditas iacens at the time of the confiscation is relevant ...

The property at issue was confiscated from GPE and PERSON , who were already dead , but were still the notional owners of the estate as it had not been acquired by an heir . The property in question was confiscated ex lege by Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . The court considers that the property could properly be confiscated in the period between the death of the testator and the time of acceptance of the estate by an heir .

On the basis of the aforementioned facts , ORG found , like ORG , that PERSON , PERSON and PERSON had been the original owners of the property which had been confiscated under Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . They were NORP nationals , and therefore the confiscation under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL had taken place in accordance with law , and the applicant ’s restitution claim falls to be considered under LAW DATE .

As the original owners did not reacquire NORP citizenship as provided for in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE , the applicant can not be considered to be entitled to restitution under this provision ... As to the remainder of the real property claimed by the applicant , it had been sold by his father before the Second World War to third persons and is , therefore excluded from restitution ... ”

On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal ( ústavní stížnost ) with ORG ( GPE soud ) . He alleged , in particular , that ORG had breached LAW freedom and equality regarding dignity and rights ) , LAW non - discrimination ) , LAW ( equal treatment ) , LAW ( the right to judicial review ) and LAW ( property rights ) of LAW ( Listina základních práv a svobod ) . He also requested that section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of Act no . CARDINAL and section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE be repealed as unconstitutional , that section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW and section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW be modified , and finally that the latter be amended to apply to the restitution rights referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) paragraphs ( o ) , ( p ) and ( r ) of LAW . He submitted , inter alia , that his stepmother had overriden her deceased sons’ succession rights in his favour and that he had been forced to leave GPE after the Second World War . He maintained that , although he had lost his NORP citizenship in DATE , it had been restored to him in DATE . Lastly , he contested ORG findings of fact and law .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal as unsubstantiated . It stated that , pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL , legal provisions which had been enacted during the NORP occupation had not formed part of the NORP legal order , save those that had not contravened LAW . In any event , Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL had annulled the applicability of all legal provisions enacted during the NORP occupation on NORP territory . The applicant ’s objection that civil cases brought by NORP citizens residing in the frontier territories of former GPE had fallen within the NORP legal order until Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL came into force , was irrelevant as the Sudetenland had been transferred to ORG by virtue of LAW , which had later been declared null and void ex tunc . The decision stated that , according to international law , the Sudetenland had not ceased to be part of NORP territory and that all legal relations on that territory had been governed by the NORP legal order .

ORG found that , under LAW , GPE and PERSON had been subject to NORP law at the time of their deaths . According to LAW , an heir acquired the estate upon its distribution . In the present case the time of acquisition of the estate and the death of the testator did not fall within DATE . In order to transfer the estate to an heir , special ex officio proceedings before the national courts had to be instituted of the court ’s own motion . If such proceedings were not instituted , the estate was hereditas iacens until delivery of a court judgment . Heirs who wished to acquire the estate had to submit an application within the framework of those proceedings . The estate was considered as being in the possession of a testator until acquired by an heir .
ORG further held as follows :

“ ... in order to determine the persons from whom the hereditas iacens property was confiscated , it is necessary to establish at what stage of the inheritance proceedings the confiscation took place . In the present case the confiscation was carried out when PERSON and PERSON were dead ; however , the estate has not yet been administered by the national authorities ... Therefore , ... the applicant has never acquired the property at issue . ”

ORG stated that as GPE and PERSON had not been entitled to claim restitution of the property under LAW and , since PERSON was of a NORP origin and had never acquired NORP citizenship , the applicant himself could not be entitled to claim restitution pursuant to LAW .
ORG also examined whether the applicant ’s right to a fair hearing had been violated in the restitution proceedings . It found no such violation .

It held lastly that , as the applicant ’s constitutional appeal was unsubstantiated , it was not possible to deal with his application to repeal , modify or amend the statutes specified by him . ORG noted that it was not a legislative body , and was therefore not empowered to enact , modify or amend statutes .

( a ) In DATE the applicant instituted inheritance proceedings before GPE ( Amtsgericht ) in respect of the property claimed in the above restitution proceedings . On DATE ORG issued CARDINAL certificates of succession ( PERSON ) to the effect that the applicant was the universal heir of his stepbrothers .

( b ) On DATE the relevant NORP authority ( ORG für die ORG der nächsten Angehörigen PERSON ehemaligen deutschen ORG ) issued a document certifying that the applicant ’s stepbrothers had not served in the ORG troops .

( c ) The applicant was the owner of real estate in ORG . This was confiscated from him pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on DATE . On DATE ORG ( PERSON okresního národního výboru v PERSON ) acknowledged the confiscation and granted him leave to appeal to ORG národní výbor v Praze ) .

( d ) On DATE ORG , considering the applicant ’s communication ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) concerning the ORG real estate at its CARDINAL session , held that LAW , read in conjunction with LAW , had been violated by GPE . It referred to its Views in cases FAC . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( Simunek et al . ) , CARDINAL ( PERSON ) and CARDINAL ( Blažek et al . ) that a legal requirement of citizenship for restitution of property previously confiscated by the authorities made an arbitrary - and consequently discriminatory - distinction between individuals who were equal victims of prior State confiscation , and constituted a violation of LAW .

LAW regulates , inter alia , the restitution of certain agricultural and other property defined in LAW which was assigned or transferred to the ORG or other legal persons DATE and DATE . Section CARDINAL ) lists the acts giving rise to a restitution claim .

The persons entitled to claim restitution ( “ rightful claimants ” ) are set out in DATE . Under section CARDINAL ) , any natural person who is a citizen of the NORP and GPE and who lost property which once formed his or her agricultural homestead in the period from DATE to DATE , in CARDINAL of the ways set out in section CARDINAL ) , is entitled to claim restitution . The entitled persons are the original owners of the property or , where the original owner is dead or reported missing without trace , the owner ’s heirs or next of kin in a specified order ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . By section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) restitution can be claimed by natural persons who are citizens of the NORP and GPE and are at the same time , in order of precedence , a ) testamentary heirs who acquired the whole of the estate , b ) testamentary heirs who acquired part of the estate , c ) children and spouses , d ) parents , or e ) brothers and sisters or their spouses and children .

As regards the procedure to be followed , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that a rightful claimant must lodge his or her claim with the appropriate ORG and , at the same time , request restitution from the person or entity concerned .
This Act constitutes a lex specialis in relation to LAW .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that any natural person who is a citizen of the NORP and GPE and lost his or her property under Presidential Decrees nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and GPE , and was loyal to the NORP State and reacquired ( NORP ) citizenship either under LAW CARDINAL , FAC and CARDINAL Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , is entitled to claim restitution of any of his or her property which passed into ORG ownership in the circumstances referred to in LAW .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that if such an entitled person died or was declared to be presumed dead before the time - limit set out in LAW , restitution can be claimed by natural persons who are citizens of the NORP and GPE and are at the same time , in order of precedence , a ) testamentary heirs who acquired the whole of the estate , b ) testamentary heirs who acquired part of the estate , c ) children or spouses , d ) parents , or e ) brothers or sisters or their children . Section CARDINALa provides that a person who satisfied the requirements set out in this LAW on DATE could file a restitution claim until DATE . His or her right lapsed if a claim was not lodged within this time - limit .

Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , amending section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , any natural person satisfying the condition of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the latter can claim restitution provided that he or she was a NORP citizen on DATE and acquired NORP citizenship either pursuant to Acts nos . CARDINAL , FAC or CARDINAL/CARDINAL , or pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , and who did not lose NORP citizenship DATE .

Article CARDINAL provides for the concept of hereditas iacens , which exists from the time of the deceased ’s death to the time when an heir accepts the estate . The principle of hereditas iacens is that , during this period , an estate is considered to be notionally owned by the deceased .

By LAW , a person who has been declared an heir by a decision of a court of law on his or her application , and who has fulfilled his or her obligations , receives the estate , thus closing the inheritance proceedings .
The Civil Code DATE was repealed at DATE , whereupon the legal concept of hereditas iacens ceased to be valid in GPE .

The decree provides for expropriation , with immediate effect and without compensation , of agricultural property for the purposes of programmed land reform . It concerns agricultural property , including buildings and movable goods , owned by persons of NORP and NORP origin irrespective of their citizenship status .
For the purposes of the land reform , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides , with immediate effect and without compensation , that the property of the following persons shall be confiscated :
a ) persons of NORP and NORP origin irrespective of their citizenship , and
b ) traitors and enemies of the ORG .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that the property of persons of NORP and NORP origin who were active in the battle for the liberation of GPE is eligible for exemption from confiscation .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that decisions as to whether the property referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) is exempt from confiscation shall be taken by ORG .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) defines persons of NORP or NORP origin as being those who , in any census after DATE , declared themselves to be of NORP or NORP origin , or who became members of national groups , formations or political parties made up of persons of NORP or NORP origin .

By DATE ( CARDINAL ) , NORP citizens of NORP or NORP origin lost their NORP citizenship on DATE when they acquired NORP or NORP citizenship pursuant to the legislation enacted by the occupying power .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided that other NORP citizens of NORP or NORP origin lost their NORP citizenship on DATE when the decree came into effect .
By DATE ( CARDINAL ) , the decree was not applicable to NORP and NORP who applied for registration as NORP or NORP during the NORP occupation .

By LAW , the NORP citizenship of the persons referred to in section CARDINAL of this Decree was retained , provided that they prove that they had been loyal to the NORP State and active in the battle for its liberation , or had suffered under NORP or fascist terror , and that they had not done any wrong to the NORP and NORP nations .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided that applications to retain NORP citizenship were to be submitted to ORG or to the appropriate embassy abroad within DATE .
Under LAW , persons who lost their NORP citizenship by virtue of LAW could claim its restoration by applying to ORG or the appropriate embassy abroad .
Persons who may be entitled to property falling under a “ dormant ” inheritance ( hereditas iacens ) can be a party to judicial or administrative proceedings .
